stakeholder: The involved stakeholders in the study on analyzing the behavioral characteristics of the elderly and young adults using deep learning are older adults, researchers, developers of AI technology, and possibly caregivers or healthcare providers.
sample_size: The sample size of the study included 50 elderly individuals and 50 young adults.
country: The participants in the study were located in Korea.
demographic: The study included 50 elderly participants, consisting of 17 males and 33 females, with an average age of 77.1 years. Additionally, there were 50 young adult participants, with 25 males and 25 females, and an average age of 23.6 years.
needs: The needs addressed by the robot in this study are related to analyzing the behavioral characteristics of the elderly and young adults based on cognitive science. The stakeholders' needs include improving elderly welfare systems, automating elderly care systems, and developing silver robots that can provide context-aware services for the elderly.
context: The study focuses on analyzing the behavioral characteristics of the elderly and young adults in a residential apartment environment. The behaviors were observed in the living room, kitchen, and bedroom of the residential apartment.
care_process: The study describes the analysis of behavioral characteristics of elderly and young adults using deep learning. It focuses on developing silver robots to provide customized services for the elderly to improve elderly welfare and automate elderly care systems. The care process described in the study is more focused on long-term care rather than early-stage or first-contact care.
methodology: The methodology used in this paper was a deep learning-based analysis of the behavioral characteristics of the elderly and young adults using explainable artificial intelligence (AI) techniques.
care_type: The study discusses the analysis of behavioral characteristics of the elderly and young adults based on cognitive science using deep learning. It aims to improve elderly welfare systems and automate elderly care systems.
robot_type: The type of robot used in the study is a silver robot.
robot_function: The general function of the robot in the study is to provide customized services for the elderly based on the analysis of their behavioral characteristics using deep learning.
facilitating_functions: The specific functions of the robot that facilitate care or assistance include analyzing behavioral characteristics, providing context-awareness, automating elderly care systems, and recognizing daily activities of the elderly.
stakeholder_facilitating: The stakeholders' characteristics that facilitate the use of the robot include their ability to adapt to physical changes, their motion strategies, and their efficiency in performing activities.
engagement: User engagement with the robot is not described or measured in the study.
key_findings: The key findings of the study include the use of deep learning to analyze the behavioral characteristics of elderly and young adults based on skeleton data. The study focused on converting skeleton data into pose evolution images (PEIs), training convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for behavior classification, and using explainable AI techniques like Grad-CAM to analyze the behavioral characteristics. The study aimed to understand the differences in behavior between the elderly and young adults through deep learning methods.

stakeholder: The involved stakeholders in the CLARC project are older adults, clinicians, researchers, developers, and hospital staff.
country: The participants were located in Spain and France.
needs: The robot addresses the need for Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA) procedures to be autonomously conducted, saving time for clinicians to focus on more valuable activities.
context: The context of the study is focused on socially assistive robots assisting in Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA) procedures for elderly people in care centers, hospitals, nursery houses, and day care centers.
care_process: The study describes the development of a socially assistive robot to help clinicians perform Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA) procedures. The care process involves autonomous driving of tests and processes by the robot to save time for clinicians. The study focuses on long-term care for elderly patients undergoing CGA procedures. It is not about first contact care.
methodology: The methodology used in this paper involved questionnaires, 20-minute debriefing sessions, and semi-directive interviews.
care_type: The study discusses Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA) procedures.
robot_type: The type of robot used in the study is a socially assistive robot.
robot_name: The robot used in the study is called CLARC.
robot_function: The general function of the robot in the study is to assist clinicians in performing Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA) procedures autonomously.
facilitating_functions: The specific functions of the robot that facilitate care or assistance include conducting Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA) tests autonomously, providing explanations, guiding patients through tests like the Get Up & Go test, and collecting data for evaluation.
stakeholder_facilitating: The stakeholders' positive feedback on usability, social acceptability, and overall user experience facilitate the use of the robot.
engagement: User engagement with the robot is described and measured through qualitative-ethnographic methods, including information on familiarity, attitude, and accessibility barriers.
acceptance: User acceptance of the robot is described and measured through feedback collected via questionnaires, debriefing sessions, and semi-directive interviews from users, including patients and medical staff.
trust: Trust in the robot is not explicitly addressed or measured in the study.
key_findings: The key findings of the study include the successful performance of the Barthel and Get Up & Go tests by the robot, challenges with the Minimental test, positive evaluations of the robot's autonomy and behavior, and favorable usability feedback on the interface with clinicians.

stakeholder: The involved stakeholders in the study are elderly participants, neuropsychologists, psychologists, and roboticists.
sample_size: The sample size of the study was 21 elderly participants.
country: The participants in the study were located in Italy.
demographic: The study involved 21 elderly participants, with an age range of 53-82 and an average age of 61.16. The participants had a range of education years from 8-18, with an average of 12.16 years.
needs: The robot in the study addresses the need for psychometric assessment of cognitive abilities in elderly individuals.
context: The study involved elderly participants in a laboratory setting that was transformed into a small furnished house to simulate a daily environment.
care_process: The study describes the process of using social robots for psychometric cognitive assessments in elderly participants. It involves administering a robotic cognitive test prototype compared to traditional paper-and-pencil assessments. The study focuses on the initial screening and assessment stage rather than long-term care or first-contact care.
methodology: The methodology used in this paper was an experiment.
care_type: The study discusses the use of social robots for psychometric assessment of cognitive abilities in elderly participants.
robot_name: The robot used in the study is the Softbank Pepper robot.
robot_function: The general function of the robot in the study is to conduct a robotic cognitive assessment for elderly participants.
facilitating_functions: The specific functions of the robot that facilitate care or assistance are speech recognition, visual recognition, face tracking, pressure sensors, and tablet interaction.
stakeholder_facilitating: The Openness to experience personality trait of the participants facilitates the use of the robot for cognitive assessment.
engagement: User engagement with the robot is not explicitly described or measured in the study. N/A
acceptance: User acceptance of the robot is described and measured in the study using the UniÔ¨Åed Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT) questionnaire.
trust: Trust in the robot is addressed in the study through a correlation analysis between the Trust construct of the UTAUT questionnaire and the supervised evaluation of Attention score.
key_findings:
The key findings of the study are:
1. Openness to experience positively influences the automatic scoring of cognitive tests conducted by a robot.
2. Anxiety correlates with supervised visuospatial capabilities.
3. Trust has a negative correlation with attention scores.
4. Intention to use correlates with delayed recall.
5. The UTAUT questionnaire revealed positive perceptions of adaptability, sociability, and usefulness of the robot.
6. Linear regression showed that Openness to experience significantly contributes to the automatic scoring.
